name: vest
content:
Add to word list
Add to word list
C1 UK (US undershirt) a type of underwear, often with no sleeves, that covers the upper part of the body, worn for extra warmth: a cotton/wool/string vest She always wore a long-sleeved thermal vest in the winter.
Dave King/Dorling Kindersley/GettyImages
UK (also vest top) a shirt without sleeves, usually made out of cotton, that is worn in the summer or for sport: The cyclists were all dressed in tight lycra shorts and the official team vest. He wore a vest top and a pair of luminous shorts to the beach party.
MarisaLia/iStock/Getty Image Plus/GettyImages
C2 US (UK waistcoat) a piece of clothing that covers the upper body but not the arms and usually has buttons down the front, worn over a shirt
AH86/iStock/Getty Image Plus/GettyImages
mainly US (UK also gilet, bodywarmer) a piece of clothing like a jacket without sleeves, that is worn over other clothes for warmth or protection: Wear something warm, like a fleece jacket or a down vest.
NAKphotos/iStock / Getty Images Plus/GettyImages
More examplesFewer examplesI always wear a vest in cold weather.We wore scratchy woollen vests when I was a boy.We stripped down to our vests.

vest noun [C]
(CLOTHING)
Add to word list
Add to word list
a piece of clothing like a coat without sleeves that reaches to the waist: My grandfather always wore his vest buttoned up. The state requires that there be a life vest for each person in the boat.
Br A vest is an undershirt.
vest verb [T]
(GIVE POWER TO)
to give someone or something the power to do something: Political power is now vested in an elected parliament.
Add to word list
Add to word list
if an employee's shares, payments to a pension plan, etc. vest or are vested, there is an agreed period that an employee must work for the company before they can use or sell them: When an employee has worked for the company for five years, their benefits shall be fully vested. Even before restricted shares vest, the employee receives ongoing dividends. Phrasal verbs
